title: Throttle and callbacks
lodash-es and lodash/fp
body:
Hi! It seems like the fp variety of lodash isn't supported in the `lodash-es` package. Is this intentional? 

I'm using CRA and would like to reduce my bundle size through tree shaking. I've read through this thread https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app/issues/1069 and it seems like the CRA's lodash babel plugin implementation is waiting for lodash v5. Is there still a way to benefit from tree shaking using `lodash/fp` and something like `lodash-es`?

title: unset multiple keys not working
isFunction has unreachable condition
body: [isFunction](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/isFunction.js#L27) using [baseGetTag](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/.internal/baseGetTag.js) ```js return tag == '[object Function]' || tag == '[object AsyncFunction]' || tag == '[object GeneratorFunction]' || tag == '[object Proxy]' ``` to polyfill on safari 9, which [does not have support for Proxy](http://caniuse.com/#search=proxy) and even if it did, the getGetTag will not return proxy

title: _.sumBy returns undefined when there's no object property matched
body:
When I use _.sumBy with property iteratee shorthand, an object with no property is counted as 0.
```javascript
_.sumBy([{name: 'a', value: 1}, {name: 'b'}], 'value')
// ==> 1
```

But, there's no object with property in list, it returns undefined.
```javascript
_.sumBy([{name: 'b'}], 'value')
// ==> undefined
```

title: Request ".quote()"
body:
Just like [string.quote()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/quote) from Mozilla, which obsolete and non-standard.
> The non-standard quote() method returns a copy of the string, replacing various special characters in the string with their escape sequences and wrapping the result in double-quotes (").

`_.quote(string, [char='"']);`
```
_.quote('Hello world!');
\\ => '"Hello world!"'

_.quote('Hello world!', "'");
\\ => "'Hello world!'"

_.quote('Hello world!', "-");
\\ => "-Hello world!-"
```
It's more readable than this:
`'"' + variable + '"'`

title: before.js was using if statement instead of while loop?

Hey there,
So I was studying source code of lodash and found this.
[Check link here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/before.js#L22)

At line 22, if using if statement here it only calls the function we passed in once even if we want it to be called multiple times.

Should it be like this:
```javascript
while (--n > 0) {
    result = func.apply(this, args)
}
```

body:
Hi,

I have severel Objects containing one sort of data:
Prices:
`'btc-usd' : 2640,
  'ltc-usd': 40, ...`
Amount of Crypto:
`'btc-usd': 2.533,
 'ltc-usd': 10.42, ...`

How can I take these Objects and create an Array of Objects like:
```
[ { name: 'Bitcoin', amount: 2.533, value: 2640, id: 'btc-usd' },
 { name: 'Litecoin', amount: 10.42, value: 40, id: 'ltc-usd' }, ...
]
```
Thanks a lot for your help!

title: Better documentation for 'predicate=_.identity'
body:
Given a method signature like [`_.remove(array, [predicate=_.identity])`](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#remove), it is not immediately apparent that you can pass an object as the predicate, i.e. `_.remove([...], {id: 'lorem'})`.

Parameter docs state: `[predicate=_.identity] (Function): The function invoked per iteration.` which doesn't give a hint about the non-function argument possibility either. Parameter description can have a link to a section in the docs describing this possibility also.

title: _.maxBy - There is something wrong
FP version of update does not work on function properties
body:
## Expected Behavior

Calling `update` on a key-path that resolves to a function causes the updater to be passed the function.

## Observed Behavior

Calling `update` on a key-path that resolves to a function causes the updater to be passed `undefined`.

## Steps to Reproduce

```js
import { update } from 'lodash/fp';

const obj = { a: 1, b: n => n * 2 };

console.log(obj.b(2)); // 4

const updatedObj = update('b', fn => n => fn(n) + 1, obj);

console.log(updatedObj.b(2)); // TypeError: fn is not a function
```

## Notes

For comparison, this works in the normal version of `lodash`:

```js
import { update } from 'lodash';

const obj = { a: 1, b: n => n * 2 };

console.log(obj.b(2)); // 4

update(obj, 'b', fn => n => fn(n) + 1);

console.log(obj.b(2)); // 5
```

title: Rationale question about _.isArrayLike & _.isArrayLikeObject
body:
I'm trying to figure out the rationale behind `isArrayLike` & `isArrayLikeObject`. Judging by their names, I reached for it on the presumption that it would cover some not-quite-array-but-array-like iterable things (like, say, `arguments` objects or custom types that extend `Array`), but the actual behavior is surprising to me, so I'd love to hear the intention from @jdalton or other maintainers.

Here's the example that surprised me:

```js
_.isArrayLikeObject('abc') // false
_.isArrayLike(new String('abc')) // true
_.isArrayLikeObject(new String('abc')) // true
```

In my particular case, this means these method aren't suited for my needs, but I'm curious what the perceived benefit of the function is, if it's treating object/boxed strings as array-like

title: Promise.resolve is not a function in _getTag.js
body:
Hello,

I'm having this error in my app:
```
invoice:225 Unhandled rejection TypeError: Promise.resolve is not a function
    at Object.eval (http://192.168.0.64/Scripts/jspm_packages/npm/lodash@4.17.4/_getTag.js:37:32)
    at eval (http://192.168.0.64/Scripts/jspm_packages/npm/lodash@4.17.4/_getTag.js:60:4)
    at eval (http://192.168.0.64/Scripts/jspm_packages/npm/lodash@4.17.4/_getTag.js:61:3)
...
```

As far as I understand lodash can't resolve promise because I have global include of bluebird.js. 
Lodash is trying to get native Promise in _Promise.js (https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.4-npm/_Promise.js):
```
var Promise = getNative(root, 'Promise')
```

Why do you need exactly native one?

title: Consider changing default _.set behavior for v5
body: I know you addressed this in #1316 but I can't comment in that one. While I think that it makes sense for setting numeric keys in existing arrays (duh), it's almost always a bug to create sparse arrays like `[undefined x 15, 'foo']`, especially considering how lodash functions differ from native array methods when handling them. Cheers!

title: Partitioner - Splitting Array into Even # Buckets (Chunkify)
body:
`lodash` should [add a new method  to handle splitting an array into equal buckets of N indexes](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40166199/split-a-group-array-of-items-into-n-groups) => the existing `chunk` method splits an array by N items in each new array index, 

.NET has a [`Partitioner`](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.concurrent.partitioner(v=vs.110).aspx)  class which achieves this when parallelizing items for batch processing scenarios or map/reduce operations.

title: Introduce a reduceWhile function?
Don't cache function result in _.once() when error thrown
body: If the first invocation of a once'd function happens to return an error then every subsequent call will also just get that cached error. It's possible that some implementations might want that error to be cached but I think most use cases wouldn't. Maybe a good compromise would be to add a flag to indicate whether or not to cache the function result if an error was thrown? The same also applies to _.memoize().

Applies an array of comparators on a value. If one fails returns false otherwise returns true.

```JavaScript
const obj =  { name: 'Dan', age: 29 };

fp.and([
    _.matches({ name: 'Dan' }),
    (dan) => dan.age > 27
], obj) // => true
```

title: Unexpected _.method behaviour when function is not defined
body:
Although this is not formalized in the docs, I expected the following law to hold

> for any object `x` and method `f`, `_.method('f')(x)` === `x.f()`

However, this does not hold for `var x = {}`:

```
> x.f()
VM451:1 Uncaught TypeError: x.f is not a function

> _.method('f')(x)
< undefined
```



This behaviour is rather [surprising](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment), and it caused a couple of my tests to report false negatives.

Is it by design? Is there a chance we could see this being changed in a future version?

title: Question - Importing single function with typescript, lodash, jest
body:
I am writing a library using typescript, jest and lodash and I would like to ship it as 2 modules -
 commonjs (for webpack 1) and with es2015 modules (for webpack 2 with tree-shaking).

What i tried:
1. `import { cloneDeep } from 'lodash';` includes whole lodash, that's no go for me
2. `import cloneDeep = require('lodash/cloneDeep');` syntax, but that can't be compiled to es2015
3. `import cloneDeep from 'lodash/cloneDeep';` doesn't work (error TS1192: Module @types/lodash/cloneDeep/index has no default export)
4. `import { cloneDeep } from 'lodash/cloneDeep';` or `import * as cloneDeep from 'lodash/cloneDeep';` doesn't work (error TS2497: Module @types/lodash/cloneDeep/index resolves to a non-module entity and cannot be imported using this construct)
5. `import * as cloneDeep from 'lodash-es/cloneDeep';` can be compiled and looks good BUT jest (I am using jest + ts-jest) fails with `SyntaxError: Unexpected token import`. This can be fixed with this approach https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42260218/jest-setup-syntaxerror-unexpected-token-export BUT then everyone with commonjs modules will have to resolve it in their setup since lodash-es is my dependency

I ended up with  `import * as cloneDeep from 'lodash.clonedeep';` which finally worked.
Is this the only way to do this? Am I missing something? If it's more typescript related problem, feel free to close this.

title: `_.every` and `_.some` naming inconsistency
body:
In previous versions of lodash, there were more aliases and `_.every` was the same as `_.all` and `_.any` was the same as `_.some`. These aliases were dropped, and now there is only one of each of them, and that's fine, but I find the particular choice of which ones to keep very surprising.

I would argue that, linguistically, these words form two distinct groups, "every" and "any" in one of them (because we tend to say "every **x**" and "any **x**"), and "all" and "some" (and, arguably, "none") in the other one (because "all _of_ **xs**", "some _of_ **xs**", and "none _of_ **xs**). But instead of `_.every` `_.any`, or `_.all` `_.some` `_.none` (if I were to choose, I'd pick the latter), we have `_.every` `_.some`.

It might feel nitpicky, and it is, but it strikes me as a departure from what appears to be the Obviously Right Choice™. Is there any good reason for this?

title: Update _.clamp documentation to denote `lower` as a required param
body:
Based on changes from this PR: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/868fd1253b18699d81fef478ad13218bbccbfd05

`lower` is no longer an optional param for `_.clamp`. [Documentation](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#clamp) should be updated to make this clear.

```javascript
_.each(obj, function(v, k) { console.log("key: " + k + " value: "+ v); });
```

outputs:

```
key: length value: ab
```
If an object contains integer "length", lodash think it's an array.

title: Flatten and unflatten objects
body:
Proposal: add `flatten` and `unflatten` functions to compress javascript objects into a single depth object.  I've already released an NPM package called [flattenizer](https://www.npmjs.com/package/flattenizer) that accomplished this.  I'd like to take it upon myself to add it to lodash.  


### Example Usage
```
> const flattenizer = require('flattenizer');
> 
> let unflattened = {
    name: 'Sean',
    city: 'Kansas City',
    favBreweries: [
        {
            name: 'Double Shift',
            favBeer: 'Sister Abbey'
        },
        {
            name: 'KC Bier Co',
            favBeer: 'Helles'
        }
    ]
};
>
> let flattened = flattenizer.flatten(unflattened)
  { name: 'Sean',
    city: 'Kansas City',
    'favBreweries.0.name': 'Double Shift',
    'favBreweries.0.favBeer': 'Sister Abbey',
    'favBreweries.1.name': 'KC Bier Co',
    'favBreweries.1.favBeer': 'Helles' }
>
> flattenizer.unflatten(flattened)
  { name: 'Sean',
    city: 'Kansas City',
    favBreweries:
     [ { name: 'Double Shift', favBeer: 'Sister Abbey' },
       { name: 'KC Bier Co', favBeer: 'Helles' } ] }
```

### API

##### flatten(unflattened)
```javascript
/**
 * Flattens an object.
 *
 * @function
 * @param {Object} unflattened     - the object to flatten
 * @param {String} [delimiter='.'] - the delimiter to be used when flattening the object
 * @returns {Object}               - the flattened object, empty if provided object is undefined
 * @throws {TypeError}             - if object passed in is not an object or if the delimiter is not a string
 * @public
 */
``` 

##### unflatten(flattened)
```javascript
/**
 * Unflattens an object with compressed keys.
 *
 * @function
 * @param {Object} flattened       - object to unflatten
 * @param {String} [delimiter='.'] - the delimiter to be used when unflattening the object
 * @returns {Object}               - the unflattened object, empty if provided object is undefined
 * @throws {TypeError}             - if object passed in is not an object or if the delimiter is not a string
 * @public
 */
```

title: find.js use to findIndex.js,But i not found findIndex.js
toLower performs join while used in chain wrapper
body:
## Description
Using the `toLower()` as part of a chain results in a join+toLower effect.

## Example
```javascript
let stringArray = ['START', 'middle', '', 'End', ''];
let result = _.chain(stringArray)
  .reject(_.isEmpty)
  .toLower()
  .value();
console.log('result', result);
``` 
### Expected Result
```javascript
[ 'start', 'middle', 'end' ]
```
### Actual Result
```javascript
'start,middle,end'
```

## Usage
Usage is pretty simple, wherever batch string manipulation is needed. (parsing and transforming data files in my case).

While this is the behavior of `_.toLower` when used directly and passing in an array of string, the notion of chain is that values are  "piped" one-by-one through the methods unless the method is an aggregator-method by nature (like `min`/`max`/`reduce` etc). I don't think this is the case for `toLower`, especially since the current result can be achieved by adding `join(',')` as the next step in the chain.

title: Documentation for `slice` does not contain examples
Slash configuration
body:
Hi, lodash is a great reference as a super-high quality package and I love many of the design decisions that you made. Speciall I like being able to do:

```js
const kebabCase = require('lodash/kebabCase');
```

And similar. In creating [the server.js package](https://github.com/franciscop/server) I am trying to achieve something similar for:

```js
const router = require('server/router');
```

Is setting all of the files to be included like this in the root the only way that you found of achieving this? Or are all the files in *lodash* on the root for other reasons? My files are in `/src` and I'd like to be able to include them straight from there as in the code examples above, but if it's not possible I'd follow lodash file configuration and just put those in the root.

title: Better documentation for lodash/fp
body:
I really like how `lodash/fp` promotes functional programming.
Unfortunately, the documentation is not very friendly to new users, especially if they are also not that familiar with lodash itself, as it is relative to the 'normal' lodash docu.
This gives me a hard time promoting its usefulness.

Would it be possible to have a stand alone `lodash/fp` documentation, with full descriptions and signatures? Maybe by programmatically merging the two?

fp.placeholder doesn't play well with fp.flow
body:
```js
const normalizeKeyName = fp.flow(
  fp.replace(fp.placeholder, ''),
  fp.replace(/^Id$/, 'userId')
)
```

Expected:

```js
> normalizeKeyName('foo ')('hello foo world')
'hello world'
```

Actual:

```
> normalizeKeyName('foo ')
'functionWrappedWithAryCurryPartialReargVarNArgumentsTZuN0Return3NLengthTTReplaceN1N2'

> normalizeKeyName('foo ')('hello foo world')
TypeError: normalizeKeyName(...) is not a function
    at repl:1:24
    at ContextifyScript.Script.runInThisContext (vm.js:23:33)
    at REPLServer.defaultEval (repl.js:334:29)
    at bound (domain.js:280:14)
    at REPLServer.runBound [as eval] (domain.js:293:12)
    at REPLServer.onLine (repl.js:531:10)
    at emitOne (events.js:101:20)
    at REPLServer.emit (events.js:189:7)
    at REPLServer.Interface._onLine (readline.js:238:10)
    at REPLServer.Interface._line (readline.js:582:8)
```

But:

```js
> normalizeKeyName('foo ', 'hello foo world')
'hell world'
```

```js
const normalizeKeyName2 = fp.flow(
  fp.replace(fp.placeholder, '')
)
```

```js
> normalizeKeyName2('foo ')('hello foo world')
'hello world'
```

title: _.isInteger()
body:
`_.isInteger(0.3)` return`true`, but `Number.isInteger(0.3)` return `false`

```js
console.log(0.3,  _.isInteger(0.3),  Number.isInteger(0.3)) // -> 0.3 true false
```

title: _.isEmptyAll()
body:
I find the need for an isEmptyAll() method for checking if one or none of several data properties exist.  Missing properties could be null, undefined, or [].

The closest I can think of to getting what I want is something like:

```
const fields = [...]

var allEmpty = [fields].every(f=>{ return _.isEmpty(f);}) 
```

which isn't bad (in ES6), but would be more convenient if it was built into lodash:

`var allEmpty = _.isEmptyAll(fields);`

title: Updated size.js documentation
body: Added documentation to the size function to show undefined and null results

title: add device.js
body:
in IOS Android and WeChat

Signed-off-by: yinhuang <yinhuang@noah-fund.com>



In China, many times we need to judge the current device environment, and many times we need to do some compatibility with WeChat, China's largest social software
So I hope merge device.js




Here are some documents

* doc
 * 
 * just in IOS 10.3.2
 * 
 * num use ' _ ' not ' . '
 * 
 * devices('IOS') //=> true
 * devices('IOS', 10) //=> true
 * devices('IOS', '10_3') //=> true
 * devices('IOS', '10.3') //=> false
 * devices('IOS', '9') //=> false
 * devices('Android') //=> false
 * 
 * 
 * just in Android 7.0.0
 * 
 * num use ' . ' not ' _ '
 * 
 * devices('Android') //=> true
 * devices('Android', 7) //=> true
 * devices('Android', '7_0') //=> false
 * devices('Android', '7.0') //=> true
 * devices('Android', '9') //=> false
 * devices('IOS') //=> false
 * 
 * just in WeChat 6.12
 * 
 * num use ' . ' not ' _ '
 * 
 * devices('WeChat') //=> true
 * devices('WeChat', 6) //=> true
 * devices('WeChat', '6_12') //=> false
 * devices('WeChat', '6.12') //=> true
 * devices('WeChat', '5') //=> false
 * devices('IOS') //=> false

title: _.fillWith
body:
Perhaps a `_.fillWith` might be added, something like:

```
_.fillWith ( array, customizer, [start=0], [end=array.length] )
```

Where the only argument `customizer` gets passed is the current index to fill.

This would enable things like:
```
_.fillWith ( Array ( 3 ), () => [] ); // => [[], [], []]
_.fillWith ( Array ( 3 ), () => _.cloneDeep ( myObj ) ); // => [{...}, {...}, {...}]
_.fillWith ( Array ( 3 ), index => 2 * index ); // [0, 2, 4]
```

Nothing super important, but seems like a nice thing to have, especially for filling an array with non-primitives. What do you think?

title: isEqual: Maps compare as equal even though insertion / value order is different
Set.forEach is not a function in firefox 24.0
A 'families' function on Collections
body:
This is related to https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2195.

I have often needed to partition a collection of things based on whether two elements in the collection belong to the same group. Say, for instance, you have a collection of things that are linked to each other one-by-one, so A is connected to C, C is connected to E and B is connected to D. I would like a function that, given A, B, C, D and E, returns two groups: one containing A, C and E and one containing B and D.

In other words, it would be very cool if there were like a ‘families’ function accepting two parameters:
- a collection, and
- a predicate of two parameters which, if it returns true, means that those two elements belong to the same group.

This would be a generalization of 'partition', in other words: 'partition', when called with predicate 'p', would call 'families' with predicate (x,y) => p(x) == p(y).

I don't know if 'families' is a good name. I was inspired by Wittgenstein's notion of family resemblance: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_resemblance

title: isEqual and NaN
lodash/fp - gt
body:
Is the argument order in curried gt from lodash/fp intentional?
Because now it works like this:

```
import { gt } from 'lodash/fp';

const isGreaterThanZero = gt(0);
isGreaterThanZero(1) // false
```

I think argument order should be reversed.

Using Lodash 4.17.2
